"It can disentangle the lower strands from the higher in that motley collection of national literature which, extending over many generations of authorship, streaked with strayed fragments of Aramaic, varying from the idyll of Ruth to the apocalyptic dreams of Daniel, and deprived by Job and Ecclesiastes of even a rambling epical unity, is naturally obnoxious to criticism when put forward as one uniform Book, still more when put forward as uniformly divine." (extremely long and complex sentence with unclear structure)
[SYNTAX]: "Its most extreme form, the iron dogma of 'scientific materialism', sought to reinterpret every aspect of history and human behaviour in its own narrow terms." (awkward structure)

"The view took root that, since people were essentially self-interested actors in matters pertaining to their economic well-being, the building of just and prosperous societies could be ensured by one or another scheme of what was described as modernization." (long and complex sentence with unclear structure)

"The fate of what the world has learned to call social and economic development has left no doubt that not even the most idealistic motives can correct materialism's fundamental flaws." (awkward and complex sentence structure)
"Tendencies once universally castigated as moral failings mutate into necessities of social progress." (awkward phrasing)

"With all the gross inequities that global integration perpetuates--indeed intensifies--no informed observer can fail to acknowledge the stimulus to reflection about reality that such changes have produced." (awkward phrasing)
